dc:description: PYCR1 was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive cutis laxa in 2009 (Guernsey DL, et al., 2009, PMID: 19576563; Reversade B, et al., 2009, PMID: 19648921). At least 40 unique variants (e.g. missense, in-frame indel, nonsense, frameshift, etc.) have been reported in humans. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data and experimental data. Variants in this gene have been reported in at least 13 probands in the two initial publications. Variants in this gene segregated with disease in two additional family members (Guernsey DL, et al., 2009, PMID: 19576563). More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence has been reached. This gene-disease relationship is supported by the function of PYCR1 in proline metabolism, its expression in bone and skin, and animal models in Xenopus and Zebrafish with partial recapitulation of disease. In summary, PYCR1 is definitively associated with autosomal recessive cutis laxa. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time.

evidence.dc:description: The homozygous missense variant Arg266Gln, at the last codon of exon 6, alters the canonical splice donor site. nested RT-PCR amplified spliced products confirmed skipping of exon 6 in patient mRNA. This variant occurs an an MAF of 0.0001416 (18/127086 alleles) in the non-Finnish european gnomAD population.

evidence.detectionMethod:
Homozygosity mapping by whole-genome SNP scanning using a high-density SNP genotyping array of approximately 330,000 biallelic markers defined a 1.4 Mbp region at 17q25.3.

Annotated coding exons were amplified from genomic DNA and sequenced with Sanger fluorescent sequencing.

The mutation segregated in the family as expected on the basis of SNP genotyping.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: sagging jowls, urinary proline at low-normal to normal levels
evidence.previousTestingDescription: One obvious gene candidate, nuclear prelamin A recognition factor (NARF), was screened first because of the association of lamin A with other progeroid genetic disorders. However, NARF did not contain any obvious causal mutations. In total, we sequenced most or all of the coding regions of 11 genes in the interval (NARF [MIM 705349], HGS [MIM 604375], HEXDC, PYCR1 [MIM 179035], RAB40B, ARHGDIA [MIM 601925], DUS1L, MRPL12 [MIM 602375], NPLOC4, RAC3 [MIM 602050], and TBCD [MIM 604649])

evidence.dc:description: The homozygous missense variant Ala179Thr is not supported by functional evidence. It is in the gnomAD non-Finnish European population at an allele frequency of 0.00004741 (6/126550).

evidence.rdfs:label: H.B.
evidence.detectionMethod: Performed genome-wide linkage analysis in 8 of 22 families (unknown if this family was included). Positional candidate genes were obtained from the GenBank and Ensembl databases. Genes were analyzed by direct sequencing of DNA with primers flanking each exon.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: proline levels low-normal, initial diagnosis of GO
evidence.previousTestingDescription: No significant expression changes in P5CS.

evidence.dc:description: The homozygous missense variant Gly206Trp was identified in patient T.P. with a reduction of protein abundance in fibroblasts, however no experimental data was provided to support the damaging effect of this variant. Extensive modeling was performed in PMID: 27677826; the results of I-Mutant and Autodock reveal reductions in both stability and cofactor binding affinity, comparative molecular dynamics simulations reveal that the variant enhances the rigidity of P5CR structure, especially that of cofactor binding site, which could result in decreased kinetics of cofactor entrance and egress.

evidence.dc:description: This model is consistent with the progeroid symptoms in humans, such as growth delay, but does not fully recapitulate skin and bone defects observed in patients.
KO fish exhibit premature aging phenotypes, such as dwarfism, slow swimming ability, loss of fertility at the age of six months, and increased mortality.
evidence.rdfs:label: Zebrafish knockout

evidence.dc:description: The Xenopus model partially recapitulated the disease with skin defects but the bone defects were not addressed in this model. A Zebrafish model was also generated with Morpholino-mediated knockdown of Pycr1 and Pycr2 causing a similar phenotype.
As in humans the Xenopus model showed obvious skin defects with skin hypoplasia and also stunted growth.
evidence.rdfs:label: Xenopus Model

evidence.dc:description: Microinjection of human PYCR1 mRNA partially rescued the phenotype with improved stunted growth. However injection of, disease associated, variant K215-D319del mRNA did not rescue.
evidence.rdfs:label: Xenopus Rescue

evidence.dc:description: Suggests that PYCR1 mutants have compromised mitochondrial function but the exact tie to disease mechanism is unclear.

After a short exposure to H2O2 a decreased mitochondrial membrane potential and a fivefold increase in cell death in affected fibroblasts compared to controls was observed. This suggests that PYCR1 is involved in the cell's response to oxidative stress.
evidence.rdfs:label: Oxidative Stress

evidence.dc:description: The role of proline in this disease is unclear but it has been proposed that proline functions in stress survival as either an osmolyte to reduce the osmotic stress, a chemical chaperone to prevent protein from aggregation, a metal chelator to chelate the toxic metals, and/or an ROS (reactive oxygen species) scavenger to reduce the ROS stress, maintain the proper NADP+/NADPH level in the cytosol, or increase total GSH (Glutathione) to protect the intracellular reduced GSH. In agreement, a role of PYCR1 in the cell's response to oxidative stress has been reported in patients (PMID: 19648921)
The low-normal levels of proline in patients is consistent with a defect in P5CR activity, which normally catalyzes the reaction: L-proline + NADP+ = 1-pyrroline-5-carboxylate + NADPH + H+.
evidence.rdfs:label: Activity Assays

evidence.dc:description: Expression of genes involved in proline metabolism in tissues from 4 day old mice were normalized to expression levels in the heart as determined by quantitative PCR. With extremely high Pycr1 expression levels in bone and skin, the two tissues most severely affected in human subjects.
evidence.rdfs:label: Murine Expression
